feed.title: What Johan Is Reading
feed.subtitle: Non-exhaustive list of books I've read and am reading, in reverse chronological order.

entry.title: Det Tredje Riket
entry.content: I loved it just as much as the first one in the series (I loved the second one less). It's something in Knausgård's language which is so, so good.

entry.title: Tunnel 29 — The True Story of an Extraordinary Escape Beneath the Berlin Wall
entry.content: This is kind of a "dramatised" documentary of actual events. Tons of historical metadata along the way. It's a bit cheesy sometimes, but I totally admit it was a page turner. And most importantly, it taught me a lot about the real life behind the Wall, in East Berlin (hint: Stasi were the biggest assholes ever).

entry.title: Berlin
entry.content: Continuing my journey towards being a fully fledged dad. 150% detailed account of the Allied invasion of Germany in 1945. So much stuff I didn't know. Lots of stories about the conditions of the soldiers, civilians, and the fates of prisoners (hint: all quite horrible).

entry.title: Tinker Tailor Solder Spy
entry.content: If I had read the book before the movie, I would've been more surprised by the climax than what I was for the film version. I continue to be impressed by le Carré's prose too. He inserts tiny words and sentences which adds character, sarcasm, and "vibe" to the current paragraph. Looking forward to the next one in the "Karla trilogy".

entry.title: The Spy Who Came In from the Cold
entry.content: Damn. I should've read this one after "The Legacy of Spies". The latter one — also by le Carré — is a prequel and sequel to "The Spy…", and I would've enjoyed "The Legacy…" more if waiting with reading it. In any case, I loved this one: a classic spy novel with "plots and counter plots", as it says on the back. I like the author's writing in the way that it's very on point. Like the world he's created, the prose is cold and without too many emotions.

entry.title: Brev från Nollpunkten
entry.content: I liked this one very much. The book is a collection of essays spanning from World War I, throughout the 1920s-30s Soviet Union with Stalin's purges, and into the architecture and bombings of Berlin and Nagasaki in World War II. The author's prose is very raw and truth-saying, but yet beautiful and carries a lot of weight. A very chilling account of the evil of man.

entry.title: The Legacy of Spies
entry.content: I'm deep into espionage fiction now. Or, I'm deep into John le Carré… This novel was both a prequel and sequel to the author's breakout piece "The Spy Who Came In from the Cold" (which I haven't read yet. Not sure if that's good or bad). I liked the prose and the pacing. His got this way of mentioning information on the fly in sentences which is very well delivered.

entry.title: Lou Reed – The Life
entry.content: How many rock bios may be allowed to have something with "life" as suffix?! What I especially liked with this book was that it was… short. I don't mean it's bad! More that all the other bios are so. Damn. Long. But Mick Wall compresses Lou Reed's life and captures the important events into an actually good read.

entry.title: Kent – Texter om Sveriges största rockband
entry.content: Collection of reviews and articles about the band Kent, from around 1993 to 2005. I liked the interviews and descriptions of their early career through newspaper texts. The band is no more since a while back, so they obviously don't do these kind of interviews any longer.

entry.title: Detaljerna
entry.content: Best book I've read for a long while. So intimate and delicate. Beautiful prose. Good build-ups. The format of describing the interactions with four people during an unspecified (but guessable) timeline from the perspective of the narrator is so cool.

entry.title: David Bowie — A Life
entry.content: A non-traditional biography of David Bowie. Being a Bowie fan, I loved it. It was constructed as interview format rather than common phrose. It was different than other biographies I've read on Bowie, thanks to the various (well known) voices the author used in the interviews. It felt personal and real.

entry.title: Grand Union
entry.content: Just didn't like it. The short stories weren't captivating enough, and the prose was elegant but unnecessarily complex.

entry.title: Four Thousand Weeks
entry.content: Too much "self help book" so far. I constantly feel: "this could've been a blog post" and "why did I buy this".

entry.title: Att Uppfinna Världen ("Inventing the World")
entry.content: Historical account about how women have been pushed aside over the years when it comes to inventions and innovation.

entry.title: Vargarna från evighetens skog
entry.content: I loved this even more than "Morgonstjärnan". It's more focused, and showcases Knausgård's ability to tell captivating stories about seemingly mundane characters and scenes. The book treats two characters' everyday life, with varying amounts of trauma and anxieties. The prose is simple: the 700 pages are an easy read. It's really inspiring.

entry.title: Jack
entry.content: The generational novel of the Swedish 1970s. Dropped it because it didn't really speak to me. I understand it must've been cool in the 70s, but not so now.

entry.title: Häng City
entry.content: Lovely rendition of a summer in the lives of three 13 year old boys in northern Sweden in 1999. The language used is so very relatable, and so are the pop culture references. Even though "nothing" really happens, the book does describe (quite accurately) feelings, energies, places, activities, and personal traits of people from the eyes of a teenage boy.

entry.title: Life
entry.content: The autobiography of Keith Richards (guitarist in Rolling Stones).

entry.title: Mastering the Art of French Cooking
entry.content: I bought the Swedish translation as paperback, and read it all in once – back to back. Quite special for a cooking book. The book includes tips and tricks around techniques, equipment, and ingredients. All the traditional French recipies are in here. What I loved about the recipies was that they were both mechanic but yet very much alive. Meaning, the authors' obsession with details, experimentation, and iteration really shined through.

entry.title: Morgonstjärnan
entry.content: I thought Knausgård would be a hard read, but it was not. "Morgonstjärnan" is so lovely. The author has this superb power of making seemingly mundane everyday people and tasks become interesting. His description are rich, and the pace is perfect. I was really captivated and inspired.

entry.title: Once Upon A Time… In Hollywood
entry.content: It's quite rare that a book is written after a film, and by the film's creator too. I loved this one: it's 100% Quentin Tarantino-ness all way through. He has space to go deeper in the conversations between the characters, whose stories he can give justice too. Like the film, it somehow entertains me without having a real plot.

entry.title: The Clash
entry.content: An okay account of the history of the band, told by themselves in interview format.

entry.title: Fight Club
entry.content: I honestly think the movie is better. I'm sure the book would be cool if I'd read that first, but I couldn't stand the fast paced dialogue with random sentences thrown in between lines.

entry.title: American Psycho
entry.content: The book is a lot more psycho than the movie. More explicit than I thought. The unreliable monologues of the narrator are amazingly written, and there are more layers to the book than just the obvious one.

entry.title: What I Talk About When I Talk About Running
entry.content: I love Murakami's straight forward language. This one made me want to start running. He's very honest about himself in this semi-biography, but never sentimental. Feels very Japanese.

entry.title: Samlade Verk
entry.content: This is an epic describing the live of a couple of individuals from the 1970s until the 2010s in Gothenburg, Sweden. It really touched me, on several layers. I'm very sentimental about the city Gothenburg, and I was constantly impressed by the cultural references, the plot, and the language of the relatively young author. There's this amazing melancholia hanging over the whole work.

entry.title: Zen Mind, Beginner's Mind
entry.content: It took me a long time to finish this very thin book. The language is dense, and I wanted to soak every page in. I had to re-read a couple of sentences. But I liked it as a whole, especially the laser focus of the author's message.

entry.title: Ishmael
entry.content: A philosophical discourse about the evolution of homo sapiens. Some things are controversial, like population control. The book's dialogue is about biodiversity, climate change, urbanisation: a lot of contemporary topics. It's a nice pairing together with Sapiens.

entry.title: Herakles
entry.content: I like mythology, especially like Greek mythology. This book is a novel – I guess a bit dramatised – about the life of the hero Hercules. It was good, very vivid and nuanced.

entry.title: Normal People
entry.content: I saw the series before reading the book, and both formats have their charm. The author has a great language, and manages to capture the atmosphere that surrounds that age from high school to university.

entry.title: Cosa Nostra
entry.content: A non-fiction history about the Sicilian mafia. Entertaining.

entry.title: About A Boy
entry.content: Very 'fun' and unforeseeable language. The thoughts of the two main characters – the man and the boy – are written in a way that feels authentic. I liked the randomness and quick turns of the book.

entry.title: Jag Kan Ha Fel
entry.content: Written by a Swedish businessman who became a Buddhist monk for 17 years. It's not a classic self help book, nor some kind of teaching about Buddhism. It's merely his story, with some of his philosophies thrown in. He mixes serious subjects with wit.

entry.title: The Godfather
entry.content: Even better than the movie. More details (of course), and deeper descriptions of characters.

entry.title: The Alchemist
entry.content: I loved it in the beginning, but then it turned out to be boring New Age-y stuff.

entry.title: The Zahir
entry.content: Like The Alchemist, this one was boring. Poorly written, boring plot, and not believable at all.

entry.title: The Snow Leopard
entry.content: A travel diary of an American in an expedition into the Himalayas. He's real goal is to catch a glimpse of the very shy Snow Leopard. This travel text captures the beauty of Zen without speaking too much about it. It's kind of dense at times, but very, very grand.

entry.title: Men Without Women
entry.content: I like short story collections, and Murakami's language is the best. Read this.

entry.title: A Little Life
entry.content: The saddest book I've read in all my life. But oh so good.

entry.title: The Mountain Shadow
entry.content: Sequel to Shantaram. Not as good, but nevertheless a good sequel.

entry.title: Dancing with the Devil in the City of God
Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance
The Holy Blood And The Holy Grail
No One Here Gets Out Alive
Led Zeppelin – When Giants Walked The Earth
Hammer of the Gods – The Led Zeppelin Saga
The Old Man and the Sea
